sentence.text: She would lay the table her own way , not the French way , and no one would reprove her for putting the forks and spoons face up .
Charles reproved her for rushing on ahead of his story , and told her about this Sergeant lurking within like a spider waiting for a juicy fly .
You will not want to reprove any children for talking during your speech .
Later he reproves himself for an impulse to be rude to a ` good auld guy " encountered during his terminal search for a bus , and we think of the prating ` good old man " Polonius .
One of the pourers reproved me for eating cheese before trying the wine .
Sometimes he reproved her weakly about the shirts .
A scientist who had the temerity to ask at Philadelphia for one was severely reproved .
He was among the Wiltshire justices reproved for obstructing royal purveyors of timber for the navy in 1637 and he refused a contribution to the expenses of the bishops ' war two years later .
Conrad was accordingly taken to task for not reporting to Rome and was ( wrongly ) reproved for taking part in the assembly .
The first week I was at the school , I attempted to climb a tree , and was reproved by a horrified prefect .
As might be expected , Evangelicals were inclined to reprove those who were reluctant to have the sacrament administered to a gravely ill patient for fear of making him lose hope of recovery .
When I suggested that The Wild Bunch was a prime example of nasty , unartistic violence , she reproved me .
Approaching the car I was driving , he reproved me , saying that a padre ought to know better .
He shot a reproving glance at Bull O'Malley .
